title: US mini-satellite firm to manufacture in SA
text:
Tyvak, an arm of parent company Terran Orbital Corporation, will shift into the Lot Fourteen hi-tech and space precinct on Adelaide's North Terrace in the CBD, formerly the site of the Royal Adelaide Hospital.

A host of space tech companies already reside at the precinct, which will be the future home of the Australian Space Agency when it shifts from temporary headquarters in Franklin Street in Adelaide at the end of 2019.

South Australian Premier Steven Marshall said securing Tyvak was a sign of the growing momentum of the space industry in the state, as he revealed he was also in touch with Elon Musk's SpaceX company to try to entice a part of their operations to the precinct.

Mr Musk's broader Tesla business already has a strong link with South Australia through the large battery storage project built in the mid-north of the state with French group Neoen to help stabilise SA's fragile electricity grid.

"We're in constant conversations with Tesla,'' Mr Marshall said.

"What Australia needs are more entrepreneurs considering the massive opportunities in space.''

'Strategic thinking'

Also on Monday, South Korean company Perigee Aerospace signed an agreement with local company Southern Launch which paves the way for small rocket launches from Southern Launch's orbital launch facility near Port Lincoln on SA's Eyre Peninsula from 2020.

Adelaide-born Andy Thomas, Australia's first NASA astronaut who was part of four space missions and is now retired from flights, said the federal government's decision to invest $150 million into the program by NASA to head to the moon again by 2024 would have important Australian payback.

"I think it's a fabulous step of strategic thinking on behalf of Australia,'' Dr Thomas said on the sidelines of an Australian Space Research Conference.

"That's a fabulous way of leveraging the investment and getting more bang for the buck so to speak."

Australian Space Agency head Megan Clark said the establishment of the agency was running a ''little bit ahead of plan'', while the cluster of space technology firms in Adelaide was building important momentum.

"We are now starting to see a centre of gravity develop in Adelaide,'' Dr Clark said.

Adelaide-based internet-of-things company Myriota in February revealed it had signed a deal with Tyvak for the supply of three nano-satellites.

Dr Villa said a mini-satellite could take between six months to 18 months to build and, depending on the specifications, could cost between $500,000 and up to $10 million.

He said the Lot Fourteen hub would potentially be too small in future years as Tyvak expanded its manufacturing operations. "Eventually we're going to build outside, somewhere else,'' he said.

The timetable would depend on the growth by customers.

"Their growth is my growth,'' Dr Villa said.
description: SA Premier Steven Marshall is trying to entice Elon Musk's SpaceX to join a growing number of space tech firms with an Adelaide address.
